name: Doubly Untrashable
description:
So basically, money up and ICE centrals up. Hard.

Keep Sundews and PADs handy and slightly ICEd, sometimes not necessary. You guys have heard of db0's Untrashable, right? Play it that way. That deck is serious business.

NAPD Contract is so good it makes creditless steals impossible.

When you've got big money up by Sundew and PADs, kill the overexerted Runner with Shinobi. Shinobi is the only way this deck flatlines, btw. No Snares, if you notice, and that's fine.

If they've got Faerie and Mimics and you want to kill with Shinobi, advance Shadows and purge counters (after having established Central forts) to force them to Faerie up. Then kill em.

Shinobi flatline them or win by taxing remote + Ash + Agendas.

name: Encrypted Perfection
description: v1: Tax the Runner and trash their programs. Score behind Chimeras or Barriers after trashing Corroder.

name: Doubly Untrashable 1.1
description:
Added Caprice Nisei (because she is awesome. // hot too).

Added Reclamation Order.

Added Snares just for added R&D oomph.

It's the same Untrashable deck that db0 put out there, with Encryption Protocols. Play it like that, ICEless or slightly ICEd Sundew / PAD servers, then towering Centrals, and a good ICEd remote server.

Caprice your HQ to stop Account Siphons, Caprice/Ash R&D for Indexings and other shenanigans. If not any of the above, Caprice + Ash a remote to start scoring.

NAPD Contract is gonna bat down the Runner's economy, and will make creditless steals impossible.

Once The Future Perfect is out, I'll definitely replace PriReq.

Go big money and flatline with Shinobi. Use Reclamation Order on Celebrity Gifts or Sundews or Encryption Protocols. Howard your Reclamation Orders.

name: [Don't play this] Jinteki Shutdown
Shut It Down
description: Shutdown(with jackson) to find shutdown so that you can reclamation the shutdowns to find more shutdown and then reclamation the shutdowns and shutdown again to shut your opponent down.

name: no dinos, no fear
description: siphon and index hard. test run femme, run, scavenge elsewhere, run. focus on centrals mostly. blackmail to outplay weyland supermodernism. float tags. be fast and furious.

name: committee trick
description: score committee with any kind of fast advance combo, then shipments from sansan wins a game in 3 turns. this deck is slow. u may try to shuffle some cheaper ice in. the ones here are very taxing, but make the game longer as u need buffer for credits to keep your hand in shape. if your meta is full of emergency shutdown - dont play it.

name: Noise - The run on the archive
description: It is my first tag-me deck.

name: Chaos Replication
description:
Use double Replicators to dig out all your hardware and get it installed, giving you lots of recurring credits to spend on icebreakers and events.

Replicators thin out the deck so that once all your hardware & programs are out, you'll hit a stage where you're drawing only resources and events, which can be played for free with Voicepad credits and eventually recycled with Levy.

Few card choice decisions: Forged Activation - combos with Cortez Chip, both recycled by Levy, can be used for early runs while you're setting up. Infiltration - just to check for traps really. Kraken - Whittles away ice in the late game.

This is just theorycrafting, I have no clue whether it works yet :) I originally made it with Kate, who seemed like the obvious choice with all the hardware you'll be installing, but I thought I'd try a Chaos Theory to really max out the small, focused deck side of things. Any suggestions on how to improve it welcome!

name: Gabriel Santiago 1st draft.o8d
CT (6th place Pyrkon)
description: inspiration from http://netrunnerdb.com/en/decklist/3173/baller-breakers-wizard-s-chest-store-championship-winner-

name: NBN (6th place Pyrkon)
TWIY Speedbumps (Pocatello, ID Store Championship 1st Place)
description: Mostly it's a typicial rush deck, good mix of ice to force the runner to install a full breaker suite while you rush out astroscripts and whatever else you can find. The key bit to this deck lies in Power Shutdown, as nearly every runner uses Corroder for a barrier breaker, you use Power Shutdown (preferably while Jackson is on the table) to blow it up, repeatedly if necessary, and buy yourself time to score behind your shiny +7 Wraparounds.

name: Compressure Kit
description:
Get either Torch or Omega quickly (doesn't matter that much for first layer of ICE, depending on ICE str you see, decide - Omega attacks all servers, Torch only one, but cheaper). Use either Modded or SMC/Clone Chip during Stimhack run to get those two expensive ones out.

You want to "compress" servers to keep them with 2 ice at most - this is done by parasiting and running with datasucker tokens. For special cases, reuse Tinkering.

Escher for a occasional surprise, if ICE you want to switch R&D/HQ pressure in late game, Inti as a counter for Wraparound which is heavy in local meta.

Your ideal starting hand should have Pro Contacts and SMC. Then, depending on the draw, either run with Stimhack and get Omega/Torch or amass some money and use Modded, if you happen to have it with breaker on hand.

name: Bichrome Paintbrush 0.2
description:
The idea behind this deck is minimize the weaknesses of a gimmicky monochromatic-Paintbrush deck by having two different types of efficient breakers to use with Paintbrush (hence, bichrome). After all, there is nothing that says that you cannot click Paintbrush to make some of the ICE into Barriers and other pieces of ICE into Code Gates, as needed. In this particular case, Yogosaurus and Corroder are your primary breakers.

Yogosaurus (or Yog by itself in the early game) can break for free: - The first ICE encountered each turn, of strength less than 5 (or 3) - All Code Gates, of strength less than 5 (or 3) - All rezzed ICE, of strength less than 5 (or 3), once Paintbrush is in play

Corroder can break for a reasonable price: - All Barriers that Yog(-osaurus)+Kit/Paintbrush cannot break - All rezzed ICE that Yog(-osaurus) cannot break, once Paintbrush is in play - Protects against Wraparound

That leaves only one thing that can ruin your day: unrezzed Sentries (and I guess gigantic, unrezzed Code Gates, but those are rarer). This deck has two solutions. First, Forged Activation Orders x3 can help rez/trash unrezzed ICE. Second, Sharpshooter saves you against the one thing that you definitely do not want to facecheck: Destroyers. Recur Sharpshooter with Clone Chips as needed to protect your main breakers.

Here is the general strategy for playing your programs. Start aggressively face-checking/FAOing ICE before you have any programs. You want everything to be rezzed for the mid-game. Then, install Sharpshooter and either Yog or Corroder (preferably using SMC), and use them to continue your aggression. Once one of your main breakers and your emergency face-check protector are in place, you can SMC/Test Run for Paintbrush, giving you a strong mono-Paintbrush build. If you installed Yog first, then you can Scavenge it onto Dinosaurus at this time, and then draw/Test Run for Corroder. If you installed Corroder first, then install Dinosaurus followed by a drawn/Test Runned Yog at your earliest convenience. You can also add some Personal Touches on either Yogosaurus or Corroder, as needed. At this point, you have an extremely efficient rig that should not require much cash to get into anything.

Your main victory condition is R&D lock. R&D Interface and Indexing are your key cards to seal the game. Same Old Thing can be an extra Indexing, Forged Activation Order, or Escher. In a pinch, it can also be used as a Scavenge or a Test Run to help build your rig or fix a broken rig.

One variation that I have been considering is to replace the Yog x2 and Corroder with Morning Star and Gordian Blade x2. This would sacrifice the cheapness of the Yog/Corroder combo for the greater strength of Morning Star and the efficiency of Gordian Blading through a whole superstack of ICE.

If Will o' the Wisp becomes a dominant card after the Lunar cycle is released, then I would drop the Personal Touches for something else--maybe another Same Old Thing or Escher or a couple Tinkerings or Levy AR Lab Accesses. By that time, there may also be some other strong counter-Wisp cards to include.

I am happy to hear suggestions for how to tweak this archetype. Is this the right amount of economy? Is the memory stuffed too tight? At the moment, there is just enough MU, but it becomes impossible to use Self-Modifying Code to get that last Corroder or Yog or Sharpshooter to finish the rig. Thanks for any feedback.

name: ReplicatingPerfection.Danbury.20140324
description: 2nd place (tiebreakers) out of 20 in Danbury store championships

name: Professor.Danbury.20140324
description: 2nd place (out of 20). Went 3-2 on the day.

name: Professor.Danbury.20140324
description: 2nd place (out of 20). Went 3-2 on the day.

name: Kate "Mac" McCaffrey(Charlottesville Store Championship 1st)
description: Not my decklist. Published with consent of player.

name: The World Is Yours* (Charlottesville Store Championship 1st)
description: Not my decklist. Published with consent of player. Enjoy!

name: New jinteki deck
Realms of Gaming - Troy, IL - Store Champion (Runner) 3/22/2
description:
Basic Gabe build with Anarch breakers.

The only thing special really was just that I use x2 Deja Vu instead of SOT. If you have SOT on the table, you advertise that you can reuse events in heap.

Deja Vu is much more versatile, and not only lets you unexpectedly recur Account Siphon or Inside Job, but also helps you recover from Power Shutdown, an unexpected Grim, or loosing cards to net damage.

name: Realms of Gaming - Troy, IL - Store Champion (Corp) 3/22/201
description:
I used only a slightly modified version of Supermodernism. Besides Jackson Howard x3 instead of Anan Tip, the only major chance was an Aggressive Secretary instead of GLC. I usually have a Tollbooth, but I was so afraid of Blackmail that I decided to include an Aggressive Secretary.

I never got a chance to use Aggressive Secretary, so I'm not sure that it was a good choice.

Based on the original Supermodernism: http://boardgamegeek.com/article/14619703#14619703

name: GRNDL - Trash All (Charlottesville Store Championship 2nd)
description:
GRNDL: Power Unleashed was the only Weyland deck at the competition. My first version of GRNDL was tag and bag and it failed miserably so I changed to the glacier approach. Also the meta is dominated by Anarch suite and Datasucker, so if you can keep the Datasucker and Corroder offline you are good. Power Shutdown is there for Datasuckers and Corroders, while a well timed Grim usually takes care of any other pesky breakers.

This deck is extremely weak to an Atman on 5 and Sharpshooter. The Charlottesville Store Champ winners' Shaper list ran 2 Sharpshooters and they are back breaking.

Elizabeth Mills surprisingly pulled her weight when a "Kit" runner had a Personal Workshop with an Omega hosted. Omega had 5 counters on it and the runner had 4 credits and I was the happiest evil corporation for a moment.

The only changes I would make would be cutting one Grim and maybe a Corporate Troubleshooter. I ran into situations where the runner would have 4 bad pub, and if they got a foothold and stole a Veterans Program, I was in trouble. Also seeing Grims and Archers in your mulligan hand are problematic. I may actually add another Elizabeth Mills to shake the Bad Pub or some Oversight AI for the Archers to put pressure on the Runner.

name: Gabriel Santiago (Charlottesville Store Championship 2nd)
description:
This is my deck. Good old criminal fun. Gabe continues to do what he does best, run hard and run fast. The only last minute change I made was adding a second Corroder because I felt program disruption may be a big factor in the tourney. Im happy that I did, because Corroder did get trashed at one point and I was thankful for the second.

Im running Decoys over Plascretes because all of the Tag and Bag decks up until recently have been running SEA Source / Posted Bounty, so I just blank those cards and have some versatility against Non-Tag and Bag decks when I Account Siphon. I did run into an NBN Tag and Bag using Midseason Replacements, so I just had to make sure I had more money at all times.

name: Paint a dinosaur
description: Use dinoyog and paintbrush to get into anything using a robust economy to back you up lategame. Would love to hear what you guys think!

name: Vanilla HB
description: FA, win games, defy change.

name: Replicated Response Team
description:
This deck is dedicated to the kill and slowing the runner down. Be it a surprise DRT... or a Snare > False Lead > Neural EMP. It's gone undefeated last weekend at my local tourney. So I'm sharing it and hope you guys like it, too, and as a way of saying thanks for sharing your excellent decklists.

I've killed more than I scored 7 points with this deck. For me, it's been very strong in the early to mid game. Very click and money intensive to trash assets thanks to Encryption Protocol. Interns is extra pesky and useful as well. With cheap ICE and drip economy. It's been quite easy to stay above 4-6 credits for me.

Smart exploring of remote servers, Keyholing, Imping HQ, Whizzard, and Net & Meat protection are probably its biggest weaknesses. I've had the fortunate opportunity to see people in my meta suit up for the Meat, but not the Net.

Inspired from the Jinteki: RP Sundew Spam and Super Modernism builds I've seen as of late...

name: I can paint
description: Paintbrush themed Code gate smasher to break though anything. Running mostly on Gordian blade and omega with paintbrush to get through pretty much any ice layer the crop decides to rez.

name: Striving for Perfection (Jinteki Q4 2013 Earnings Call)
description:
*** Jinteki Q4 2013 Earnings Call & Netcast Transcript ***

OPERATOR: Good day, and welcome to Jinteki's fourth quarter 2013 Results Conference Call. At this time, I would like to turn the call over to Mr. Toshiyuki Sakai for introductory remarks.

-- Slide: Jinteki Q4 2013 Earnings Call --

SAKAI: We announced Jinteki's fourth quarter and full year 2013 results after the close of trading today. The shareholder letter and financial results are all available at our Investor Relations site, as will be the netcast for this call.

Our goal this last quarter at Jinteki was to implement an overwhelming number of assets and upgrades, requiring opposing runners to spend two clicks to access our remote servers during their turns. As previously forecasted, damage-dealing and expensive-to-break ICE have made it costly for runners to hit or bounce off our central servers just to attack our assets, especially with the introduction of Encryption Protocols. While it's true that this partnership with our competitor Haas-Bioroid is a significant change in direction for the company, we've been eager to build on the encouraging results reported by db0's Untrashable trials and our own in-house experiments with variants.

-- Slide: Credits Rule Everything Around Me // Econ --

We are pleased to report a number of initiatives and fixed assets that have helped generate a healthy drip economy for Jinteki in the previous fiscal year, if not a flood. While this approach is vulnerable to attacks from outside forces -- unlike previous lucrative efforts made possible by tiny giraffes -- runners often ignore our consumer-targeted PAD Campaigns due to high trash costs.

And thanks to Sundews, Jinteki's revenues have increased dramatically year-over-year for the quarter. Runners tend to attack those more than our PAD Campaigns, but light ICE can ward them off until we can deluge our remote servers with assets. And if we expect to lose an initial Sundew anyway -- and if we have a back-up prepared -- placing an ICE heavy with routines that can serve as the foundation for a super server has proven to be beneficial. Even when we've elected not to rez it, the threat tends to give runners pause. And we have recruited several talented students from Levy University as interns to recover and re-install lost Sundews.

We also recently brought in the esteemed Jackson Howard to assist with our cloning initiatives at Jinteki. He's been invaluable in not only helping accelerate R&D on Sundews, but also provoking runners to spend two clicks to approach him, and resurrecting cancelled but promising projects.

I will now turn the call over to Chairman Hiro to share the measures we've taken this previous quarter with cutting our operating costs.

--- Slide: Protect Ya Neck // Traps ---

HIRO: As you know, we retired our long-running Junebug bioengineering project to make way for inexpensive Shocks, which have performed splendidly in deterring unwarranted access to Jinteki's HQ, R&D labs, and especially Archives. We have continued to support Snares as an additional disincentive, and employ a Ronin as both a distraction and a potential punishment for careless runners.

We have capitalized on Hokusai Grids built to protect weak points where runners can access, serving as stopgaps until we can install stronger ICE. These facilities are expensive for intruders to disable, and runners sometimes avoid them completely, expecting them to be safeguarded by Ash and Caprice. When we've taken advantage of the Grid to install certain confidential AI agendas in a lightly protected or unprotected server, it's been to our benefit, as runners must pay a pound of flesh to acquire those agendas -- we've also been able to turn around and convert those vulnerable facilities into super servers for future use.

-- Slide: Only Built for Caprice Linx // Upgrades --

As Mr. Sakai noted earlier, we have partnered with Haas-Bioroid for a limited exchange of tech, which includes the company's Ash bioroid. Intruders to our servers will need to waste another click, as well as additional credits in their repeated run through our ICE, to access any assets or agendas, provided we can outspend them through trace bids.

We have also recently welcomed Ms. Caprice Nisei back to the fold and integrated her into our countermeasures, utilizing the uncanny abilities and detective skills she picked up during her time working with New Angeles PD to block illegal incursions into our central and remote servers.

For runners who do manage to make it past our defenses and even siphon our funds, we have an agreement with media corporation NBN allowing us to track these criminals when possible to close their accounts. Furthermore, we've created a joint venture for a new program that encourages runners to make a move when they otherwise wouldn't want to, or generate free credits when they delay their attacks. We are considering other alternatives to disrupt runner activity, too.

Our sysop Midori will be able to talk more about the lengths we've gone to in order to protect our servers.

-- Slide: Clan In Da Front // ICE --

MIDORI: Okay, while we tend to push out much fewer ICE than some of our competitors, we try to make up for it with adaptable ICE like Chimera, cheap but annoying ICE like Yagura, and expensive-to-break Tsurugis. Yeah, we've taken some flack for using Shinobi ICE, but believe me, no low-link hacker wants to run into one of those on a central server before attempting a remote run. Still, we are looking into eventually replacing our Shinobis with Komainus, if not other alternatives.

We've also borrowed NBN's RSVP ICE that makes it extremely difficult for runners to trash our assets, not to mention to get through Caprice or Ash. We have agendas that intruders won't be able to even take away with them unless they can break RSVP's subroutine, that's how great the ICE is.

If we need to make adjustments to our setup, we have the option of bringing in Akitaro to get everything loaded -- keeping those Chimeras up is no sweat for him. Just don't ask how he does it, haha.

I think that's all I had to mention regarding our ICE. I'll hand this back over to our chairman.

-- Slide: Can It All Be So Simple // Agendas --

HIRO: Thank you, Midori. Before we get into the Q&A, I'd like to mention that we have some very exciting opportunities ahead of Jinteki, including improvements on our Nisei line that allow us to further delay would-be hackers. And thanks to our ties to the New Angeles PD -- through Commissioner Dawn and Ms. Caprice Nisei's work there -- as well as the nature of our classified projects, it's become more difficult and expensive for runners to steal our work. With developments down the line like our Future Perfect program, we can make it near impossible.

We also have other non-cloning advancements we'll announce in the near future, coming out of our biomedical Harmony Medtech division and our stealth groups at the Tennin Institute. That's not to say we intend to pivot our focus away from cloning, however. Cloning has the potential to replicate perfection. Let me repeat that: cloning has the potential to replicate perfection. Should we aspire to anything less?

With that, I'd like to open the call to questions.

name: Come Closer (Ottawa/Montreal Store Championships, 1st place)
description:
Winning Corp deck for the following two SCs:

Boutique FDB 2014-03-22 Store Championship - Ottawa / Gatineau

Randolph Pub 2014-03-23 Store Championship - Montreal

I also "stream" OCTGN games with commentary to youtube, come check me out! :D http://www.youtube.com/user/Lop3rt

name: Ser Lopert (Ottawa/Montreal Store Championships, 1st place)
description:
Deckname is: Ser Gabriel / Shadowhunter vLopert

Winning Corp deck for the following two SCs:

Boutique FDB 2014-03-22 Store Championship - Ottawa / Gatineau

Randolph Pub 2014-03-23 Store Championship - Montreal

I also "stream" OCTGN games with commentary to youtube, come check me out! :D http://www.youtube.com/user/Lop3rt

name: HBFA Clearance - 1st place 2014 Two Cats Store Championship
description: Two Cats San Francisco 4-0 Runner, 4-0 Corp

name: Chaos Replication
HB Pyrkon
description: Money, money, money and big ice. If you survive early game then you can win even from 0:6/0:5 as happened yesterday on Pyrkon :)

name: Chaos Replication 2
Chaos_Pyrkon
description: This deck should surprise corpo as main pressure goes on HQ instead of RD which is not usual in Shaper. There is also possibility to switch strategy mid-game and start pressure RD from medium. I thought it works quite ok based on many wins on OCTGN, but on yesterdays tournament where I only won one game with it I rather change my mind :)

name: Kit's Tricky to Rock a Run
description:
It's tricky, tricky, tricky!

I've been playing a variation of this deck for quite a while and I think it's in a good spot finally. I took it to a store championship this last weekend and it went 3-0. The deck is superb in the early game and forces the Corp to quickly lay down ICE in ways that they probably wouldn't prefer under normal circumstances. In the later game using Scavenge/Clone Chip/SMC allows you to get into 3+ deep servers that the Corp didn't think you had access to. I prefer City Hall over Plascrete because it has more practical uses and with two Levys in the deck you should be fine taking damage as long as it's not lethal. The deck can have money issues but I've found that against certain decks taking 6 from Magnum and then running is pretty efficient.

name: Chaos Replication - Now I think finalized :)
Double Trouble
description: A remake of "the gold crown" (a kit combo deck with Test Run, Scavenge and Eureka). The 40-cards deck should help find the right cards at the right time. 5MU means that you can have a full rig without any additional source of memory (1torch, 1battering ram, 2femmes). The Woman In The Red Dress is there for some kind of multi-access, and is tutorisable. It seemed to do well in Lodan's 'In a red dress and alone' deck. At last, the event economy should be great with Professional Contacts. I can't wait to try this list out!

name: Breakin' Breakers / Jinteki Rig Destroyer
description:
I used to run neural EMP, Punitive Counterstrike, and Fenris to try and flatline the runner, but I've found most players are usually cautious enough to draw up and prevent this from happening.

Since most runners are anticipating neural EMPs / etc, they spend a lot of time defending against these things whether or not they're actually in your deck. I've found it's better to let runners freak out when their hand size gets to low while I focus my real energy on messing up crucial programs and combos. Power Shutdown makes quick work of corroders, which is lovely when you've got Wraparound, and Rototurret / Archer / Ichi make for solid surprise program trashing. All the other net damage serves to hopefully break crucial combos and to freak the runner out / force them to spend time prepping for flatline cards that never really come.

Thinking about sticking a Caprice in here, maybe instead of one of the sentry ice or subliminal messaging, although I love that card and am reluctant to drop it.

name: Buggy Chess
description:
This used to be a full Caissa deck, but I've since then cut the Bishops, Pawns, and Deep Reds. My experiences with this setup is to run aggressively early to mid game while being naked. Reina should never be played like a Shaper. Only develop the rig as problems show up.

Knights and Rooks are amazing for pressuring the Corp's servers, but they are fairly click-intensive. Depending on the situation, they might need to be installed the turn prior to the main runs. In addition, due to the restricted clicks when playing around with the Caissas, Daily Casts are preferred to provide a some what steady economy.

Lastly... go nuts with the Account Siphons, a poor Corp makes a happy Runner (upwards of 6 times). Usually the deck could float in tags, just exercise caution against possible Socrch-candidates. I.e. NBN/Weyland.

name: Weyland Tag'n Bag the old fashion way
description:
No Accelerated-nonsense, just plain Weyland being what they are good at: Money and Scorches. The flatlining with Scorches are mostly an alternative win condition that strives on the careless, or simple pure luck on the Corp draws.

Everyone should have faced this type of deck already, thus they are usually very careful when running to prevent being Scorched. Due to the cheap end-the-run ICES, the deck may score a few early over advanced Project Atlas or The Cleaners. Use the Hostile Takeovers either for Archer-food, or as game closing agendas when searched out with Project Atlas.

Simple and exciting deck to play with or against by the Runner.

name: Next Initiative
NBN UofMCSSA Round 1
description: First round of our weekly deck duels No stats were recorded for this deck

name: Jinteki RP 0.1
Pyrkon 2014 Winner
description: (im just a deck publisher)

name: Pyrkon 2014 Winner
description: (im just a deck publisher)

name: Capri Sun(dew)
description:
First published deck so please tear it up :D

Beginnings of a Replicating Perfection tax deck with the new Dbl time pack.

Agendas are 3/2 scores, Gilas for econ if needed as Sundews are drawing massive focus, Score Clone Retirements from hand to clear Bad Pub from your Shinobis or to force match point and pressure. Trying out various NAPD contracts

Assets: Caprice is pretty sweet. She's before successful access but after your tax ICE and if you have a Nisei scored they wont get into a remote that turn without some serious resource expenditure and luck. I can see Ash as being another way to preserve the server integrity. strongbox might be another way as well with the click demands. Sundews are awesome, 2 out for a cpl of turns is game winning. Gilas are there if they focus the sundews, you can often score agendas around them so much do ppl hate them :D. Slow advancing a Ronin can often be used to buy you a turn or get the kill from a snare or Shinobi, increasingly enjoying this card

ICE: Using the Box on remotes as solid ETR early on. Marker on any other ICE can provide ETR plus hefty tax, especially on Bioroids. Combined with RP where clicks are at a premium it seems to work. RSVP into Shinobi has been nice. Chum into Shinobi also works. I tend to get Yaguras onto RnD and Archives for the dmg tax (that combined with hitting a snare often leaves ppl expsoed for a Ronin) and minor Rnd protection. Crims need some heavy duty over HQ so I might put RSVP and Shinobi there or a Tsurugi but let them in with tax and Caprice them away.

Its still early, I dont entirely like the balance of my ICE as its a bit 'combo' ish but I've managed a steady run of wins on OCTGN and found it really enjoyable to play. Please let me know where I might improve it.

name: Striving for Perfection (Jinteki Q4 2013 Earnings Call Trans
description:
*** Jinteki Q4 2013 Earnings Call & Netcast Transcript ***

OPERATOR: Good day, and welcome to Jinteki's fourth quarter 2013 Results Conference Call. At this time, I would like to turn the call over to Mr. Toshiyuki Sakia for introductory remarks.

-- Slide: Jinteki Q4 2013 Earnings Call --

SAKAI: We announced Jinteki's fourth quarter and full year 2013 results after the close of trading today. The shareholder letter and financial results are all available at our Investor Relations site, as will be the netcast for this call.

Our goal this last quarter at Jinteki was to overwhelm the market with assets and upgrades, requiring opposing runners to spend two clicks to access our remote servers during their turns. And if we expect to lose an initial Sundew anyway -- and if we have a back-up prepared -- placing an ICE heavy with routines that can serve as the foundation for a super server has proven to be beneficial. Even when we've elected not to rez it, the threat tends to give runners pause. And we have recruited several talented students from Levy University as interns to recover and re-install lost Sundews.

We also recently brought in the esteemed Jackson Howard to assist with our cloning initiatives at Jinteki. He's been invaluable in not only helping accelerate R&D on Sundews, but also provoking runners to spend two clicks to approach him, and resurrecting cancelled but promising projects.

I will now turn the call over to Chairman Hiro to share the measures we've taken this previous quarter with cutting our operating costs.

--- Slide: Protect Ya Neck // Traps ---

HIRO: As you know, we retired our long-running Junebug bioengineering project to make way for inexpensive Shocks, which have performed splendidly in deterring unwarranted access to Jinteki's HQ, R&D labs, and especially Archives. We have continued to support Snares as an additional disincentive, and employ a Ronin as both a distraction and a potential punishment for careless runners.

We have capitalized on Hokusai Grids built to protect weak points where runners can access, serving as stopgaps until we can install stronger ICE. These facilities are expensive for intruders to disable, and runners sometimes avoid them completely, expecting them to be safeguarded by Ash and Caprice. When we've taken advantage of the Grid to install certain confidential AI agendas in a lightly protected or unprotected server, it's been to our benefit, as runners must pay a pound of flesh to acquire those agendas -- we've also been able to turn around and convert those vulnerable facilities into super servers for future use.

-- Slide: Only Built for Caprice Linx // Upgrades --

As Mr. Sakai noted earlier, we have partnered with Haas-Bioroid for a limited exchange of tech, which includes the company's Ash bioroid. Intruders to our servers will need to waste another click, as well as additional credits in their repeated run through our ICE, to access any assets or agendas, provided we can outspend them through trace bids.

We have also recently welcomed Ms. Caprice Nisei back to the fold and integrated her into our countermeasures, utilizing the uncanny abilities and detective skills she picked up during her time working with New Angeles PD to block illegal incursions into our central and remote servers.

For runners who do manage to make it past our defenses and even siphon our funds, we have an agreement with media corporation NBN allowing us to track these criminals when possible to close their accounts. Furthermore, we've created a joint venture for a new program that encourages runners to make a move when they otherwise wouldn't want to, or generate free credits when they delay their attacks. We are considering other alternatives to disrupt runner activity, too.

Our sysop Midori will be able to talk more about the lengths we've gone to in order to protect our servers.

-- Slide: Clan In Da Front // ICE --

MIDORI: Okay, while we tend to push out much fewer ICE than some of our competitors, we try to make up for it with adaptable ICE like Chimera, cheap but annoying ICE like Yagura, and expensive-to-break Tsurugis. Yeah, we've taken some flack for using Shinobi ICE, but believe me, no low-link hacker wants to run into one of those on a central server before attempting a remote run. Still, we are looking into eventually replacing our Shinobis with Komainus, if not other alternatives.

We've also borrowed NBN's RSVP ICE that makes it extremely difficult for runners to trash our assets, not to mention to get through Caprice or Ash. We have agendas that intruders won't be able to even take away with them unless they can break RSVP's subroutine, that's how great the ICE is.

If we need to make adjustments to our setup, we have the option of bringing in Akitaro to get everything loaded -- keeping those Chimeras up is no sweat for him. Just don't ask how he does it, haha.

I think that's all I had to mention regarding our ICE. I'll hand this back over to our chairman.

-- Slide: Can It All Be So Simple // Agendas --

HIRO: Thank you, Midori. Before we get into the Q&A, I'd like to mention that we have some very exciting opportunities ahead of Jinteki, including improvements on our Nisei line that allow us to further delay would-be hackers. And thanks to our ties to the New Angeles PD -- through Commissioner Dawn and Ms. Caprice Nisei's work there -- as well as the nature of our classified projects, it's become more difficult and expensive for runners to steal our work. With developments down the line like our Future Perfect program, we can make it near impossible.

We also have other non-cloning advancements we'll announce in the near future, coming out of our biomedical Harmony Medtech division and our stealth groups at the Tennin Institute. That's not to say we intend to pivot our focus away from cloning, however. Cloning has the potential to replicate perfection. Let me repeat that: cloning has the potential to replicate perfection. Should we aspire to anything less?

With that, I'd like to open the call to questions.

name: Rop'aDopeDope
description:
It seemed a good idea at the time.

...but after Drew, she never was the same. I couldn't help her.

There was only one thing left to do really; buy a puppy.

With 13 Run Events the idea is to break easily centrals(early bird + doppleganger is awesome) for use notoriety and for access assets with quest completed.

it could be really cool but no idea if it could work...some tips?
